canonical_explanation.text: Reproduction is the biological process by which organisms produce offspring, ensuring the continuity of species. It involves DNA copying, which introduces variations essential for evolution. Asexual reproduction involves a single parent and produces genetically identical offspring. Methods include binary fission (Amoeba), budding (Hydra, yeast), fragmentation (Spirogyra), regeneration (Planaria), spore formation (Rhizopus), and vegetative propagation (potato, rose). Sexual reproduction involves two parents and produces offspring with genetic variation through the fusion of male and female gametes. In flowering plants, the flower is the reproductive organ — stamens produce pollen (male) and carpels contain ovules (female). Pollination, fertilization, and seed/fruit formation complete the cycle. In humans, the male reproductive system produces sperm (testes) and the female system produces ova (ovaries). Fertilization occurs in the fallopian tube, and the embryo develops in the uterus.
rules: Reproduction ensures continuity of species and introduces variation through DNA copying.
Asexual reproduction: single parent, no gamete fusion, offspring genetically identical to parent.
Binary fission: parent cell divides into two equal halves (Amoeba, bacteria).
Budding: a small outgrowth develops into a new organism (Hydra, yeast).
Sexual reproduction involves fusion of male and female gametes (fertilization).
In flowers: stamen (anther + filament) is male; carpel/pistil (stigma + style + ovary) is female.
Pollination transfers pollen from anther to stigma; fertilization occurs when pollen tube reaches ovule.
In humans: sperm + ovum → zygote → embryo → foetus; placenta nourishes the developing embryo.

questions.question_text: Binary fission is a mode of asexual reproduction commonly seen in:
questions.explanation_correct: Binary fission is commonly seen in Amoeba and bacteria. In this process, the parent organism divides into two equal halves, each developing into a complete new organism. The nucleus divides first (amitosis), followed by the cytoplasm.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Hydra reproduces by budding. Planaria reproduces by regeneration. Spirogyra reproduces by fragmentation. Amoeba specifically reproduces through binary fission.

questions.question_text: Which organism reproduces by budding?
questions.explanation_correct: Hydra reproduces by budding. A small outgrowth (bud) develops on the body of the parent organism. The bud grows, develops tentacles and a mouth, and eventually detaches to become an independent organism. Yeast also reproduces by budding.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Amoeba reproduces by binary fission. Spirogyra reproduces by fragmentation. Rhizopus reproduces by spore formation. Hydra (and yeast) are the classic examples of organisms that reproduce by budding.

questions.question_text: Spore formation as a method of reproduction is seen in:
questions.explanation_correct: Rhizopus (bread mould) reproduces by spore formation. It produces spores inside structures called sporangia. These spores are covered by thick walls that protect them from unfavourable conditions. When conditions are favourable, spores germinate to form new organisms.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Amoeba uses binary fission. Hydra uses budding. Planaria uses regeneration. Rhizopus is the classic example of an organism that reproduces through spore formation.

questions.question_text: Regeneration as a mode of reproduction is seen in:
questions.explanation_correct: Planaria (a flatworm) can reproduce by regeneration. If its body is cut into several pieces, each piece can grow into a complete new organism. This is because Planaria has specialised cells that can differentiate into various cell types to form a whole organism.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Yeast reproduces by budding. Rhizopus reproduces by spore formation. Amoeba reproduces by binary fission. Planaria is the classic example of an organism capable of regeneration.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is an example of vegetative propagation?

options.text: Growing a new plant from a potato tuber

questions.explanation_correct: Growing a new plant from a potato tuber is vegetative propagation — a type of asexual reproduction in plants where new plants grow from vegetative parts (roots, stems, leaves) of the parent plant. The 'eyes' on a potato tuber are buds that can sprout into new plants.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Pollination and fertilization are parts of sexual reproduction. Spore formation is asexual but not vegetative propagation. Growing a plant from a potato tuber (vegetative part) is specifically vegetative propagation.

questions.question_text: The male reproductive part of a flower is the:
questions.explanation_correct: The stamen is the male reproductive part of a flower. It consists of two parts: the anther (which produces pollen grains containing male gametes) and the filament (a thin stalk that supports the anther).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The carpel (pistil) is the female reproductive part. Petals are colourful parts that attract pollinators. Sepals are green leaf-like structures that protect the flower bud. The stamen is the male reproductive organ.

questions.question_text: The part of the carpel that contains the ovules is the:
questions.explanation_correct: The ovary is the swollen base of the carpel (pistil) that contains the ovules. Each ovule has an egg cell (female gamete). After fertilization, the ovule develops into a seed and the ovary develops into a fruit.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The stigma is the sticky top of the carpel that receives pollen. The style is the tube connecting the stigma to the ovary. The anther is part of the stamen (male part). The ovary is the part of the carpel that houses the ovules.

questions.question_text: In human males, sperm is produced in the:
questions.explanation_correct: The testes are the male reproductive organs that produce sperm (male gametes) and the hormone testosterone. They are located outside the body in a pouch called the scrotum, which maintains a temperature lower than body temperature, necessary for sperm production.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The prostate gland and seminal vesicles produce fluids that form part of semen. Vas deferens is the tube that transports sperm from the testes. Only the testes produce sperm.

questions.question_text: Fertilization in humans takes place in the:
questions.explanation_correct: Fertilization (fusion of sperm and ovum) in humans takes place in the fallopian tube (oviduct). The ovum released from the ovary travels through the fallopian tube, where it meets the sperm. The resulting zygote then moves to the uterus for implantation.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The uterus is where the embryo implants and develops, not where fertilization occurs. The ovary produces and releases eggs. The vagina is the passage for sperm entry. Fertilization specifically happens in the fallopian tube.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a barrier method of contraception?
questions.explanation_correct: A condom is a barrier method of contraception that physically prevents the meeting of sperm and egg. It is a thin rubber covering worn during intercourse that blocks the passage of sperm. Barrier methods also include diaphragms.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Oral pills are chemical (hormonal) methods. Copper-T is a device (IUD) placed in the uterus. Surgical methods involve vasectomy or tubectomy. Condoms are barrier methods that physically prevent sperm from reaching the egg.

questions.question_text: Fragmentation is a mode of asexual reproduction seen in:
questions.explanation_correct: Spirogyra (a filamentous alga) reproduces by fragmentation. The filament breaks into two or more fragments, and each fragment grows into a new organism. This happens when the filament reaches a certain size and breaks at weak points.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Hydra reproduces by budding. Amoeba reproduces by binary fission. Yeast reproduces by budding. Spirogyra is the classic example of reproduction by fragmentation.

questions.question_text: Asexual reproduction produces offspring that are genetically identical to the parent.
questions.explanation_correct: This is true. In asexual reproduction, offspring are produced from a single parent by mitotic cell division. Since there is no fusion of gametes and no mixing of genetic material from two parents, the offspring are genetically identical to the parent (clones).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is true. Asexual reproduction involves only mitosis, producing exact copies of the parent's DNA. Only minor variations may arise from errors during DNA copying.

questions.question_text: The transfer of pollen from anther to stigma of the same flower is called cross-pollination.
questions.explanation_correct: This is false. The transfer of pollen from the anther to the stigma of the same flower (or another flower on the same plant) is called self-pollination. Cross-pollination is the transfer of pollen from the anther of one flower to the stigma of a flower on a different plant of the same species.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Self-pollination occurs within the same flower or plant. Cross-pollination requires pollen transfer between different plants. The statement incorrectly labels self-pollination as cross-pollination.

questions.question_text: The placenta provides nourishment to the developing embryo in the uterus.
questions.explanation_correct: This is true. The placenta is a disc-like structure that develops in the uterus during pregnancy. It is embedded in the uterine wall and is connected to the embryo through the umbilical cord. It provides oxygen, nutrients, and removes waste products from the developing embryo.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is true. The placenta acts as the interface between the mother and the foetus. It facilitates the exchange of gases, nutrients, and waste products through the mother's blood supply.

questions.question_text: The process of growing new plants from vegetative parts like stems, roots, and leaves is called ___ propagation.
questions.explanation_correct: Vegetative propagation is a form of asexual reproduction in plants where new plants grow from vegetative parts (stems, roots, leaves) rather than from seeds. Examples include potato tubers, onion bulbs, ginger rhizomes, and rose cuttings.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'vegetative'. This type of propagation uses plant parts other than seeds to produce new plants. It is widely used in agriculture and horticulture for clonal propagation of desirable plant varieties.

questions.question_text: After fertilization in a flower, the ovule develops into a ___ and the ovary develops into a fruit.
questions.explanation_correct: After fertilization, the ovule develops into a seed (containing the embryo and food reserves), while the ovary wall ripens and develops into a fruit. The fruit protects the seeds and aids in their dispersal.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'seed'. The ovule contains the fertilized egg cell which develops into an embryo enclosed within the seed coat. The ovary simultaneously develops into the fruit that surrounds the seed.

questions.question_text: The fusion of male and female gametes is called ___.
questions.explanation_correct: Fertilization is the process of fusion of a male gamete (sperm) with a female gamete (ovum/egg) to form a zygote. In humans, this occurs in the fallopian tube. The zygote then undergoes cell division to eventually form an embryo.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'fertilization'. It is the defining event of sexual reproduction where genetic material from both parents combines. The resulting zygote has a complete set of chromosomes — half from each parent.

questions.question_text: The surgical method of contraception in males, where the vas deferens is cut and tied, is called ___.
questions.explanation_correct: Vasectomy is a surgical contraceptive method in males where the vas deferens (the tubes that carry sperm from the testes) are cut, tied, or sealed. This prevents sperm from being ejaculated. The corresponding procedure in females is called tubectomy.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'vasectomy'. It is a permanent surgical method of male sterilization. The vas deferens is cut and sealed, blocking the passage of sperm. In females, the equivalent procedure (cutting fallopian tubes) is called tubectomy.

questions.question_text: In tissue culture, new plants can be grown from a small piece of plant tissue in a nutrient medium.
questions.explanation_correct: This is true. Tissue culture (micropropagation) is a technique where small pieces of plant tissue (explants) are grown on a sterile nutrient medium containing plant hormones. The cells divide and differentiate to form a complete new plant. This technique is used for rapid multiplication of desirable plant varieties.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is true. Tissue culture allows production of many genetically identical plants from a small tissue sample. It is widely used commercially for orchids, bananas, and other high-value crops.

questions.question_text: A flower that contains both stamens and carpels is called:
questions.explanation_correct: A bisexual (or hermaphrodite/perfect) flower contains both male (stamens) and female (carpels/pistils) reproductive parts. Examples include hibiscus, rose, and mustard. A unisexual flower has only one type of reproductive organ.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A unisexual flower has either stamens or carpels, not both. An incomplete flower lacks one or more of the four whorls. A male flower has only stamens. A bisexual flower has both stamens and carpels.

questions.question_text: Why does Amoeba use binary fission while Plasmodium (malaria parasite) uses multiple fission?

options.text: Plasmodium needs to produce many offspring simultaneously to ensure survival inside the host
Binary fission is faster than multiple fission

questions.explanation_correct: Plasmodium uses multiple fission because it is a parasite living inside a host. By dividing into many daughter cells simultaneously, it increases its chances of infecting more red blood cells and surviving the host's immune response. Amoeba, being a free-living organism, only needs to divide into two.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Size is not the determining factor. Speed is not the reason either. Plasmodium can technically undergo binary fission but uses multiple fission as a survival strategy. The key reason is the need to produce many offspring at once for survival in a hostile host environment.

questions.question_text: A gardener grows new rose plants from stem cuttings. This is advantageous because:

options.text: The new plants retain all desirable traits of the parent plant
It is the only way to grow roses

questions.explanation_correct: Vegetative propagation through stem cuttings produces plants that are genetically identical to the parent plant. This means all desirable traits (colour, fragrance, size) of the parent rose are preserved in the offspring. This is why gardeners prefer this method for ornamental and commercial plants.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Vegetative propagation does not introduce genetic variation — it produces clones. Roses can also be grown from seeds. Cuttings do not produce seeds. The main advantage is preserving the exact genetic traits of a desirable parent plant.

questions.question_text: Why is regeneration in Planaria considered reproduction but not in lizards that regrow their tails?

options.text: In Planaria, a body fragment grows into a complete new organism; a lizard only regrows a lost body part
Lizards do not have regenerative cells

questions.explanation_correct: In Planaria, if the body is cut into pieces, each piece can develop into a complete, independent new organism — this is true reproduction. In lizards, only the lost tail regrows; the tail fragment cannot develop into a new lizard. This is repair/regeneration of a body part, not reproduction.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Size and complexity are not the determining factors. Lizards do have some regenerative ability. The key difference is whether a body fragment can develop into a complete new organism (reproduction in Planaria) versus just regrowing a lost part (repair in lizards).

questions.question_text: Why is cross-pollination considered advantageous over self-pollination?

options.text: It is simpler and does not require pollinators
It introduces genetic variation in offspring, making them more adaptable
It does not require a stigma

questions.explanation_correct: Cross-pollination transfers pollen between different plants of the same species, combining genetic material from two parents. This introduces genetic variation in the offspring, making the species more adaptable to changing environments and more resistant to diseases. Self-pollination produces genetically similar offspring with less variability.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Cross-pollination is actually more complex and usually requires pollinators. It does not produce more pollen. Both types require a stigma. The key advantage is increased genetic diversity and adaptability in offspring.

questions.question_text: Why are the testes located outside the body in the scrotum in human males?

options.text: There is no space inside the body
Sperm production requires a temperature 2-3°C lower than body temperature
To protect the testes from internal organs

questions.explanation_correct: The testes are located in the scrotum outside the body because spermatogenesis (sperm formation) requires a temperature 2-3°C lower than normal body temperature (37°C). The scrotum provides this cooler environment, which is essential for the proper formation and survival of sperm.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Space is not the reason — the body cavity has enough room. Protection is not the primary purpose. Ease of release is not related to external positioning. The temperature requirement for sperm production is the specific reason for external placement.

questions.question_text: A copper-T (IUD) is placed in the uterus to prevent pregnancy. How does it work?

options.text: It prevents implantation of the fertilized egg in the uterus

questions.explanation_correct: The Copper-T (intrauterine device) is placed inside the uterus where it creates an environment that is hostile to sperm and prevents the implantation of a fertilized egg in the uterine wall. The copper ions released by the device also have spermicidal effects.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The IUD does not directly kill egg cells or prevent ovulation (that is the function of hormonal pills). It does not block the fallopian tubes (that is tubectomy). The Copper-T primarily works by preventing implantation and creating a hostile uterine environment.

questions.question_text: After fertilization, the petals and stamens of a flower usually fall off because:

options.text: They have served their purpose and are no longer needed

questions.explanation_correct: Petals attract pollinators and stamens produce pollen — both are needed for pollination and fertilization. Once fertilization is complete, these parts have served their purpose. They wither and fall off to allow the ovary to develop into a fruit and the ovule into seeds, conserving the plant's energy and resources.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Pollinators do not damage petals enough to make them fall. Wind is not the primary cause. The fruit does not physically push them off. These parts fall naturally because their biological role in reproduction is complete after fertilization.

questions.question_text: What is the role of the placenta during pregnancy?

options.text: It provides oxygen and nutrients to the embryo and removes waste

questions.explanation_correct: The placenta is a specialised tissue embedded in the uterine wall that connects the developing embryo/foetus to the mother's blood supply through the umbilical cord. It facilitates the exchange of oxygen, nutrients (glucose, amino acids), and waste products (CO₂, urea) between the mother and the foetus.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Sperm is produced by the testes. Egg cells are produced by ovaries. The menstrual cycle is regulated by hormones from the ovaries and pituitary gland. The placenta's primary role is nourishing the developing embryo and removing its waste.

questions.question_text: Why does sexual reproduction produce more variations than asexual reproduction?

options.text: Because it involves fusion of gametes from two different parents, combining their genetic material

questions.explanation_correct: Sexual reproduction produces more variations because it involves the fusion of gametes from two genetically different parents. The combination of genetic material from two sources creates unique offspring. Additionally, crossing over during meiosis and random assortment of chromosomes further increase genetic diversity.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Speed, number of offspring, and energy are not the reasons for more variation. The key factor is the combination of genetic material from two different parents through gamete fusion, creating new gene combinations in each offspring.

questions.question_text: What is the function of the pollen tube during fertilization in plants?

options.text: It carries pollen to another flower
It grows from the stigma through the style to carry male gametes to the ovule
It protects the pollen grain from drying
It absorbs water for the pollen grain

questions.explanation_correct: When a pollen grain lands on the stigma, it germinates and produces a pollen tube that grows down through the style to reach the ovule in the ovary. The pollen tube carries the male gametes (two sperm cells) to the ovule, where fertilization (fusion of gametes) takes place.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The pollen tube does not carry pollen to other flowers — that is pollination. It is not primarily for protection or water absorption. The pollen tube is a pathway that delivers male gametes from the pollen grain on the stigma to the ovule inside the ovary.

questions.question_text: The menstrual cycle in human females is approximately 28 days long.
questions.explanation_correct: This is true. The menstrual cycle is approximately 28 days long. It involves the preparation of the uterine lining for possible pregnancy. If the egg is not fertilized, the thickened uterine lining breaks down and is shed along with blood through menstruation, which lasts about 3-5 days.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is true. The average menstrual cycle is about 28 days, though it can vary slightly. It involves ovulation around day 14 and menstruation at the beginning of the cycle if no pregnancy occurs.

questions.question_text: The technique of growing new plants from a small piece of plant tissue in an artificial nutrient medium is called ___.
questions.explanation_correct: Tissue culture (also called micropropagation) involves growing plant cells or tissues in a sterile nutrient medium containing growth hormones under controlled conditions. It can produce thousands of genetically identical plants from a small tissue piece, making it useful for commercial plant propagation.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'tissue culture'. This technique exploits the totipotency of plant cells — the ability of any plant cell to develop into a complete organism when given the right conditions and hormones.

questions.question_text: The transfer of pollen grains from the anther to the stigma of a flower is called ___.
questions.explanation_correct: Pollination is the process of transferring pollen grains from the anther (male part) to the stigma (female part) of a flower. It can be self-pollination (within the same flower or plant) or cross-pollination (between different plants). Agents of pollination include wind, water, insects, and birds.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'pollination'. It is the first step in sexual reproduction in flowering plants, followed by pollen tube growth and fertilization.

questions.question_text: The structure that connects the developing embryo to the mother's uterine wall is the ___.
questions.explanation_correct: The placenta is a disc-shaped structure that develops during pregnancy and is embedded in the uterine wall. It is connected to the embryo/foetus through the umbilical cord. It facilitates the exchange of nutrients, oxygen, and waste between the mother and the developing baby.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'placenta'. It acts as the vital link between the mother and the foetus, serving as the organ for nutrient supply, gas exchange, and waste removal throughout pregnancy.

questions.question_text: Why should contraceptive methods be adopted?

options.text: Only to prevent sexually transmitted diseases
To control population growth and plan families, as well as prevent STDs
Only to increase the gap between children

questions.explanation_correct: Contraceptive methods serve multiple purposes: controlling population growth, enabling family planning, maintaining adequate gaps between children for the health of mother and child, and preventing sexually transmitted diseases (STDs). They are an important aspect of reproductive health.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Contraception is not only about preventing STDs or spacing children. It serves comprehensive reproductive health goals including population control, family planning, maternal health, and STD prevention.

questions.question_text: Compare binary fission in Amoeba with budding in yeast. Which statement correctly distinguishes them?

options.text: In binary fission, the parent divides into two equal halves; in budding, an unequal outgrowth separates from the parent
Binary fission involves two parents; budding involves one parent
Both are exactly the same process
Budding produces two equal offspring; binary fission produces unequal offspring

questions.explanation_correct: In binary fission (Amoeba), the parent cell divides into two approximately equal daughter cells. In budding (yeast, Hydra), a small bud (outgrowth) develops on the parent body, grows, and eventually detaches as a new smaller organism. The key difference is equal vs unequal division.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Both are asexual reproduction involving a single parent. They are not the same process. In binary fission, division is equal; in budding, the bud is smaller than the parent. Option A correctly describes this difference.

questions.question_text: Describe the process of fertilization in a flower from the time pollen lands on the stigma.

options.text: Pollen → Stigma → Ovary → Pollen tube → Ovule → Fertilization
Pollen → Stigma → Pollen tube grows through style → Reaches ovule → Male gamete fuses with egg → Zygote formed

questions.explanation_correct: After pollen lands on the stigma, it germinates and produces a pollen tube that grows down through the style to reach the ovule inside the ovary. The pollen tube releases two male gametes into the ovule. One male gamete fuses with the egg cell (fertilization) to form a zygote, which develops into an embryo.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct sequence must include pollen tube growth through the style, not directly to the ovary. The pollen reaches the stigma first, not the style or ovule. Option B correctly describes the step-by-step process of fertilization in flowering plants.

questions.question_text: What happens during menstruation, and why does it occur?

options.text: A new egg is produced; it occurs every 14 days
The thickened uterine lining breaks down and is expelled because no fertilized egg has implanted
Fertilization takes place; it occurs once a month
Hormones are released to start pregnancy

questions.explanation_correct: Menstruation occurs when the egg released during ovulation is not fertilized. The thickened, blood-rich uterine lining that had prepared for the implantation of a fertilized egg is no longer needed. It breaks down and is shed along with blood through the vagina, lasting about 3-5 days. This cycle repeats approximately every 28 days.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Menstruation is the shedding of the uterine lining, not the production of eggs (that is ovulation). Fertilization does not occur during menstruation. Hormones during menstruation signal the start of a new cycle, not pregnancy.

questions.question_text: Why is variation important for a species? Consider environmental changes.

options.text: Variations allow some individuals to survive in changed environments, ensuring species survival
Variation only affects appearance, not survival

questions.explanation_correct: Variation is crucial for species survival because if all organisms were identical, a single environmental change (disease, climate change) could wipe out the entire population. Variations ensure that some individuals have traits that make them better adapted to survive in changed conditions, allowing the species to continue.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Variation produces diversity, not identical organisms. It does not weaken the species — it strengthens it. Variation affects many traits including survival ability, not just appearance. Variation provides the raw material for natural selection and adaptation.

questions.question_text:
Assertion: Flowers that are pollinated by wind are usually small, dull-coloured, and without nectar.
Reason: Wind-pollinated flowers do not need to attract insects.

options.text: Both assertion and reason are true, and reason is the correct explanation
Both are true, but reason is not the correct explanation
Assertion is true but reason is false
Both assertion and reason are false

questions.explanation_correct: Both are true and the reason correctly explains the assertion. Wind-pollinated flowers are small, dull-coloured, without fragrance or nectar because they rely on wind, not insects, for pollen transfer. They instead produce large quantities of light pollen that can be easily carried by wind. Bright colours and nectar would be wasteful since insects are not needed.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The assertion is correct — wind-pollinated flowers are indeed small and dull. The reason is also correct — they don't need insect attractants. The reason explains why these flowers lack the features typically associated with insect-pollinated flowers.

questions.question_text: Draw the human female reproductive system. Which sequence correctly traces the path of the egg?
questions.explanation_correct: The correct path of the egg is: Ovary (egg released during ovulation) → Fallopian tube (where fertilization may occur) → Uterus (where the fertilized egg implants and develops; if unfertilized, the lining is shed) → Vagina (through which menstrual flow exits). This is an important diagram-based question for CBSE exams.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The egg is first released from the ovary, then travels through the fallopian tube (not directly to the uterus). The uterus receives the egg from the fallopian tube. The correct anatomical path is Ovary → Fallopian tube → Uterus → Vagina.

questions.question_text: Which of the following STDs is caused by a virus?
questions.explanation_correct: AIDS (Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome) is caused by HIV (Human Immunodeficiency Virus). It weakens the immune system by destroying helper T-cells (CD4 cells), making the person vulnerable to opportunistic infections. Gonorrhoea and syphilis are bacterial STDs.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Gonorrhoea is caused by the bacterium Neisseria gonorrhoeae. Syphilis is caused by the bacterium Treponema pallidum. Trichomoniasis is caused by a protozoan parasite. AIDS is the STD caused by a virus (HIV).

questions.question_text: List two advantages of vegetative propagation over sexual reproduction in plants.

options.text: More genetic variation and stronger plants
Faster reproduction and preservation of desirable parental traits
Requires two parents and produces seeds
Produces more fruit and requires less water

questions.explanation_correct: Two key advantages of vegetative propagation: (1) It is faster than sexual reproduction because it bypasses the stages of flower formation, pollination, and seed germination. (2) It preserves all the desirable characteristics of the parent plant exactly, since offspring are genetic clones.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Vegetative propagation produces less genetic variation (clones), not more. It requires only one parent and does not produce seeds. Water requirement is not significantly different. The correct advantages are speed and preservation of parental traits.

questions.question_text: What is the significance of the seed in sexual reproduction of plants?

options.text: Seeds contain the embryo, provide nutrition for germination, and have a protective coat for dispersal
Seeds only provide food for animals
Seeds are formed only during asexual reproduction

questions.explanation_correct: Seeds are highly significant: they contain the embryo (next generation plant), endosperm/cotyledons (food reserves for germination), and a tough seed coat (testa) that protects against adverse conditions. Seeds can remain dormant until conditions are favourable and can be dispersed to new locations.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Seeds are extremely important in plant reproduction. They are not formed during asexual reproduction. While some seeds are eaten by animals, that is not their primary significance. Seeds protect the embryo, store food, and enable dispersal.

questions.question_text: Explain why the human embryo requires a special connection with the mother's body for development.

options.text: Because the embryo can produce its own food
Because the embryo needs continuous supply of oxygen, nutrients, and removal of waste, which the placenta provides
Because the embryo does not need any nourishment
Because the embryo develops outside the uterus

questions.explanation_correct: Unlike eggs of birds or reptiles that have stored yolk, the human embryo develops inside the uterus and requires a continuous supply of oxygen, glucose, amino acids, and other nutrients from the mother's blood. The placenta provides this connection, and waste products (CO₂, urea) are also removed through it. This is essential for the 9-month development period.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The embryo cannot produce its own food and definitely needs nourishment. It develops inside the uterus, not outside. The placenta is essential because the human embryo has no stored food and depends entirely on the mother for nutrition and waste removal.

questions.question_text: DNA copying during reproduction is not always perfectly accurate, which is a source of variation.
questions.explanation_correct: This is true. During DNA replication, the copying process is not always 100% accurate. Small errors (mutations) can occur, leading to variations in the offspring. While most variations are minor, some can be significant and may be advantageous, neutral, or harmful for survival.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is true. DNA copying always has a small margin of error. These errors create variations that are the basis of evolution and the diversity of life. Without these variations, species could not adapt to changing environments.

questions.question_text: Oral contraceptive pills work by preventing the release of the egg (ovulation) through hormonal changes.
questions.explanation_correct: This is true. Oral contraceptive pills contain synthetic hormones (usually estrogen and progesterone) that prevent ovulation by disrupting the normal hormonal cycle. Without the release of an egg from the ovary, fertilization cannot occur.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is true. Oral pills are a hormonal method of contraception that prevents the ovary from releasing an egg. They alter the hormonal balance to suppress ovulation, making pregnancy impossible.

questions.question_text: In Rhizopus, the blob-like structures that contain spores are called ___.
questions.explanation_correct: Sporangia (singular: sporangium) are the round, blob-like structures at the tips of the upright hyphae of Rhizopus (bread mould). They contain numerous spores. When the sporangium bursts, spores are released into the air and can germinate into new organisms under favourable conditions.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'sporangia'. These are the spore-bearing structures of Rhizopus. Each sporangium contains hundreds of spores that are dispersed by air currents for reproduction.

questions.question_text: A flower that has either stamens or carpels but not both is called a ___ flower.
questions.explanation_correct: A unisexual flower contains either the male reproductive part (stamens) or the female reproductive part (carpels), but not both. Examples include papaya and watermelon flowers. In contrast, a bisexual flower contains both stamens and carpels (e.g., hibiscus, mustard).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'unisexual'. Such flowers are either male (with stamens only, called staminate flowers) or female (with carpels only, called pistillate flowers). Corn, papaya, and cucumber have unisexual flowers.

questions.question_text: The cell formed by the fusion of an egg and a sperm is called a ___.
questions.explanation_correct: A zygote is the single cell formed when a male gamete (sperm) fuses with a female gamete (egg/ovum) during fertilization. The zygote contains the complete set of chromosomes — half from each parent. It undergoes repeated cell division to develop into an embryo.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'zygote'. It is the first cell of a new organism, containing genetic material from both parents. In humans, the zygote forms in the fallopian tube and then implants in the uterus to develop further.
